DataElement.preferredName: Disease International Classification of Diseases Anatomic Site Classification Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the words related to the group of named location based on the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology used principally in tumor and cancer registries for coding the site (topography) of neoplasms in description of an anatomical region or of a body part.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Disease International Classification of Diseases Anatomic Site Classification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the group of named location based on the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology used principally in tumor and cancer registries for coding the site (topography) of neoplasms in description of an anatomical region or of a body part.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.

Concepts.definition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Property.preferredName: International Classification of Diseases Anatomic Site Classification
Property.preferredDefinition: A system of categories to which morbid entries are assigned according to established criteria. Included is the entire range of conditions in a manageable number of categories, grouped to facilitate mortality reporting. It is produced by the World Health Organization. The Clinical Modifications, produced by the United States Dept. of Health and Human Services, are larger extensions used for morbidity and general epidemiological purposes, primarily in the U.S.:Named locations of or within the body.:A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

Concepts.definition: A system of categories to which morbid entries are assigned according to established criteria. Included is the entire range of conditions in a manageable number of categories, grouped to facilitate mortality reporting. It is produced by the World Health Organization. The Clinical Modifications, produced by the United States Dept. of Health and Human Services, are larger extensions used for morbidity and general epidemiological purposes, primarily in the U.S.
Named locations of or within the body.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

DataElementConcept.origin: COG CRF:Children's Oncology Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the words of the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology used principally in tumor and cancer registries for coding the site (topography) and the histology (morphology) of neoplasms in description of an anatomical region or of a body part.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Text; the words of something written.

ValueDomain.origin: COG CRF:Children's Oncology Group Case Report Form
